DOCNAME: CASE OF CHAHAL v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 3;Violation of Art. 5-4;Violation of Art. 13;No violation of Art. 5-1;Not necessary to examine Art. 8;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The CARDINAL applicants are members of the same family and are NORP . ORG The first applicant , PERSON , is an NORP citizen who was born in DATE . He entered GPE illegally in DATE in search of employment . In DATE he applied to ORG to regularise his stay and on DATE was granted indefinite leave to remain under the terms of an amnesty for illegal entrants who arrived before DATE . Since DATE he has been detained for the purposes of deportation in FAC . ORG

The second applicant , PERSON , is also an NORP citizen who was born in DATE . She came to GPE on DATE following her marriage to the first applicant in GPE , and currently lives in GPE with the CARDINAL children of the family , PERSON ( born in DATE ) and PERSON ( born in DATE ) , who are the third and fourth applicants . By virtue of their birth in GPE the CARDINAL children have NORP nationality .
CARDINAL . The first and second applicants applied for NORP citizenship in DATE . PERSON request was refused on DATE but that of PERSON is yet to be determined .

CARDINAL . Since the partition of GPE in DATE many NORP have been engaged in a political campaign for an independent homeland , ORG , which would approximate to the NORP province of GPE . In DATE , a prominent group emerged under the leadership of PERSON , based at FAC in GPE , the holiest NORP shrine . The Government submit that PERSON , as well as preaching the tenets of orthodox NORP , used FAC for the accumulation of arms and advocated the use of violence for the establishment of an independent GPE .

CARDINAL . The situation in GPE deteriorated following the killing of a senior police officer in FAC in DATE . On DATE the NORP army stormed the temple during a religious festival , killing PERSON and CARDINAL other NORP . DATE the NORP Prime Minister , PERSON , was shot dead by CARDINAL NORP members of her bodyguard . The ensuing NORP backlash included the killing of CARDINAL NORP in riots in GPE .

CARDINAL . Since DATE , the conflict in GPE has reportedly claimed CARDINAL lives , peaking in DATE when , according to NORP press reports collated by ORG , CARDINAL people were killed in related incidents in GPE and elsewhere . There is evidence of violence and human rights abuses perpetrated by both NORP separatists and the security forces ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON travelled to GPE with his wife and children to visit relatives . He submits that during this visit he attended at FAC on many occasions , and saw PERSON preach there approximately CARDINAL times . On CARDINAL occasion he , his wife and son were afforded a personal audience with him . At around this time Mr PERSON was baptised and began to adhere to the tenets of orthodox NORP . He also became involved in organising passive resistance in support of autonomy for GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE he was arrested by the GPE police . He was taken into detention and held for DATE , during which time he was , he contended , kept handcuffed in insanitary conditions , beaten to unconsciousness , electrocuted on various parts of his body and subjected to a mock execution . He was subsequently released without charge .
He was able to return to GPE on DATE , and has not visited GPE since .

CARDINAL . On his return to GPE , PERSON became a leading figure in the NORP community , which reacted with horror to the storming of FAC . He helped organise a demonstration in GPE to protest at ORG actions , became a full - time member of the committee of the " gurdwara " ( temple ) in PERSON ( FAC , PERSON ) and travelled around GPE persuading young NORP to be baptised .

CARDINAL . In DATE Mr PERSON Rode entered GPE . He was PERSON nephew , and recognised by NORP as his successor as spiritual leader . PERSON contacted him on his arrival and toured GPE with him , assisting at baptisms performed by him . Mr Rode was instrumental in setting up branches of ORG ( " ISYF " ) in GPE , and the applicant played an important organisational role in this endeavour . The ISYF was established to be the overseas branch of the All India Sikh Students ' Federation . This latter organisation was proscribed by ORG until DATE , and is reportedly still perceived as militant by the NORP authorities .

CARDINAL . In DATE Mr Rode was excluded from GPE on the ground that he publicly advocated violent methods in pursuance of the separatist campaign . On his return to GPE he was imprisoned without trial until DATE . Shortly after his release it became apparent that he had changed his political views ; he now argued that NORP should pursue their cause using constitutional methods , a view which , according to the applicants , was unacceptable to many NORP . The former followers of PERSON Rode therefore became divided .

CARDINAL . In GPE , according to the Government , this led to a split in the ISYF along broadly north / south lines . In the north of GPE most branches followed Mr Rode , whereas in the south the ISYF became linked with another GPE political activist , Dr PERSON , who continued to support the campaign for an independent homeland . PERSON and , according to him , all major figures of spiritual and intellectual standing within the GPE Sikh community were in the southern faction .

CARDINAL . In DATE Mr PERSON was detained under the Prevention of Terrorism ( Temporary Provisions ) Act DATE ( " PTA " ) on suspicion of involvement in a conspiracy to assassinate the NORP Prime Minister , Mr PERSON , during an official visit to GPE . He was released for lack of evidence .

In DATE he was arrested and questioned twice ( once under the ORG ) , because he was believed to be involved in an ISYF conspiracy to murder moderate NORP in GPE . On both occasions he was released without charge . PERSON denied involvement in any of these conspiracies .

CARDINAL . In DATE he was charged with assault and affray following disturbances at the GPE gurdwara in GPE . During the course of his trial on these charges in DATE there was a disturbance at the GPE gurdwara , which was widely reported in the national press . PERSON was arrested in connection with this incident , and was brought to court in handcuffs on DATE of his trial . He was convicted on both charges arising out of the ORG incident , and served concurrent sentences of DATE .
He was subsequently acquitted of charges arising out of the PERSON disturbance .
On DATE ORG quashed the CARDINAL convictions on the grounds that Mr PERSON 's appearance in court in handcuffs had been seriously prejudicial to him .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Home Secretary ( Mr PERSON ) decided that PERSON ought to be deported because his continued presence in GPE was unconducive to the public good for reasons of national security and other reasons of a political nature , namely the international fight against terrorism .

A notice of intention to deport was served on the latter on DATE . He was then detained for deportation purposes pursuant to paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of Schedule III of LAW DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and has remained in custody ever since .

CARDINAL . PERSON claimed that if returned to GPE he had a well - founded fear of persecution within the terms of ORG ( " LAW " - see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and applied for political asylum on DATE . He was interviewed by officials from ORG on DATE and his solicitors submitted written representations on his behalf . ORG
He claimed that he would be subjected to torture and persecution if returned to GPE , and relied upon the following matters , inter alia : ORG
( a ) his detention and torture in GPE in DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) ;
( b ) his political activities in GPE and his identification with the regeneration of the NORP religion and the campaign for a separate NORP ORG ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) ;
( c ) his links with PERSON and PERSON ; ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) ;

( d ) evidence that his parents , other relatives and contacts had been detained , tortured and questioned in DATE about PERSON activities in GPE and that others connected to him had died in police custody ; ORG
( e ) the interest shown by the NORP national press in his alleged NORP militancy and proposed expulsion from GPE ; ORG

( f ) consistent evidence , including that contained in the reports of ORG , of the torture and murder of those perceived to be NORP militants by the NORP authorities , particularly the GPE police ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG Secretary refused the request for asylum . ORG In a letter to the applicant , he expressed the view that the latter 's known support of NORP separatism would be unlikely to attract the interest of the NORP authorities unless that support were to include acts of violence against GPE . He continued that he was

" not aware of any outstanding charges either in GPE or elsewhere against [ Mr PERSON ] and on the account [ Mr Chahal ] has given of his political activities , the Secretary of ORG does not accept that there is a reasonable likelihood that he would be persecuted if he were to return to GPE . The media interest in his case may be known by the NORP authorities and , given his admitted involvement in an extremist faction of the LAW , it is accepted that the ORG may have some current and legitimate interest in his activities " . ORG
The Home Secretary did not consider that PERSON experiences in GPE in DATE had any continued relevance , since that had been a time of particularly high tension in GPE .

CARDINAL . PERSON 's solicitors informed the ORG Secretary that he intended to make an application for judicial review of the refusal of asylum , but would wait until the advisory panel had considered the national security case against him .

CARDINAL . Because of the national security elements of the case , there was no right of appeal against the deportation order ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) . However , on DATE , the matter was considered by an advisory panel , chaired by a ORG judge , Lord Justice Lloyd , and including a former president of ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG had prepared statements on DATE and CARDINAL DATE containing an outline of the grounds for the notice of intention to deport , which were sent to the applicant . The principal points were as follows :
( a ) PERSON had been the central figure in directing the support for terrorism organised by the GPE - based faction of the ORG which had close links with NORP terrorists in the GPE ; ORG
( b ) he had played a leading role in the faction 's programme of intimidation directed against the members of other groups within the GPE Sikh community ; ORG
( c ) he had been involved in supplying funds and equipment to terrorists in GPE since DATE ; ORG

( d ) he had a public history of violent involvement in NORP terrorism , as evidenced by his DATE convictions and involvement in disturbances at the GPE gurdwara ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . These disturbances were related to the aim of gaining control of gurdwara funds in order to finance support and assistance for terrorist activity in GPE ; ORG
( e ) he had been involved in planning and directing terrorist attacks in GPE , GPE and elsewhere .
PERSON was not informed of the sources of and the evidence for these views , which were put to the advisory panel .
CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE , PERSON solicitors set out a written case to be put before the advisory panel , including the following points : ORG
( a ) the southern branch of the ORG had a membership of CARDINAL and was non - violent both in terms of its aims and history ; ORG

( b ) the ISYF did not attempt to gain control of gurdwaras in order to channel funds into terrorism ; this was a purely ideological struggle on the part of young NORP to have gurdwaras run according to NORP religious values ; ORG
( c ) PERSON denied any involvement in the disturbances at FAC and GPE gurdwaras ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) or in any other violent or terrorist activity in GPE or elsewhere .

CARDINAL . He appeared before the panel in person , and was allowed to call witnesses on his behalf , but was not allowed to be represented by a lawyer or to be informed of the advice which the panel gave to the Home Secretary ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Home Secretary ( PERSON ) signed an order for PERSON deportation , which was served on DATE . ORG

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE PERSON applied for judicial review of the Home Secretaries ' decisions to refuse asylum and to make the deportation order . Leave was granted by ORG on DATE . ORG The asylum refusal was quashed on DATE and referred back to the ORG Secretary . The court found that the reasoning behind it was inadequate , principally because the ORG Secretary had neglected to explain whether he believed the evidence of ORG relating to the situation in GPE and , if not , the reasons for such disbelief . The court did not decide on the validity of the deportation order . Mr Justice PERSON expressed " enormous anxiety " about the case .

CARDINAL . After further consideration , on DATE the ORG Secretary ( PERSON ) took a fresh decision to refuse asylum . He considered that the breakdown of law and order in GPE was due to the activities of NORP terrorists and was not evidence of persecution within the terms of LAW . Furthermore , relying upon ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of that Convention ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , he expressed the view that , even if PERSON were at risk of persecution , he would not be entitled to the protection of the DATE Convention because of the threat he posed to national security .
CARDINAL . PERSON applied for judicial review of this decision , but then requested a postponement on DATE , which was granted .

CARDINAL . In a letter dated DATE , the ORG Secretary informed the applicant that he declined to withdraw the deportation proceedings , that PERSON could be deported to any international airport of his choice within GPE and that the ORG Secretary had sought and received an assurance from ORG ( which was subsequently repeated in DATE ) in the following terms :

" We have noted your request to have a formal assurance to the effect that , if Mr PERSON were to be deported to GPE , he would enjoy the same legal protection as any other NORP citizen , and that he would have no reason to expect to suffer mistreatment of any kind at the hands of the NORP authorities . ORG
I have the honour to confirm the above . "

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted leave to apply for judicial review of the decisions of DATE to maintain the refusal of asylum and of CARDINAL DATE to proceed with the deportation . An application for bail was rejected on DATE ( ORG was not provided with details of this ruling ) .

CARDINAL . ORG ) quashed PERSON DATE convictions on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The Home Secretary reviewed the case in the light of this development , but concluded that it was right to proceed with the deportation .

CARDINAL . The hearing of the application for judicial review took place DATE . It was refused on DATE by Mr Justice PERSON in ORG , as was a further application for bail ( ORG was not provided with details of this ruling either ) .
CARDINAL . PERSON appealed to ORG . The appeal was heard on DATE and dismissed on DATE ( NORP v. Secretary of ORG for ORG , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] ORG , p. CARDINAL ) .

The court held that the combined effect of LAW and the Immigration Rules ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) was to require the Home Secretary to weigh the threat to PERSON life or freedom if he were deported against the danger to national security if he were permitted to stay . In the words of Lord Justice PERSON : PERSON

" The proposition that , in deciding whether the deportation of an individual would be in the public good , the Secretary of ORG should wholly ignore the fact that the individual has established a well - founded fear of persecution in the country to which he is to be sent seems to me to be surprising and unacceptable . Of course there may very well be occasions when the individual poses such a threat to this country and its inhabitants that considerations of his personal safety and well - being become virtually irrelevant . Nonetheless one would expect that the Secretary of ORG would balance the risks to this country against the risks to the individual , albeit that the scales might properly be weighted in favour of the former . "

The Home Secretary appeared to have taken into account the evidence that the applicant might be persecuted and it was not possible for the court to judge whether his decision to deport was irrational or perverse because it did not have access to the evidence relating to the national security risk posed by PERSON . As Lord Justice PERSON remarked : PERSON

" The court has the right to scrutinise a claim that a person should be deported in the interests of national security but in practice this scrutiny may be defective or incomplete if all the relevant facts are not before the court . "
In the absence of evidence of irrationality or perversity , it was impossible under LANGUAGE law to set aside the Home Secretary 's decision ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . ORG refused leave to appeal to ORG , and this was also refused by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . Following the report of the ORG , the applicant applied for temporary release pending the decision of ORG , by way of habeas corpus and judicial review proceedings in ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The Secretary of ORG opposed the application on the following grounds : ORG

" The applicant was detained in DATE and served with notice of intention to deport because the then Secretary of ORG was satisfied that he represented a substantial threat to national security . The Secretary of ORG remains satisfied that such a threat persists ... Given the reasons for the applicant 's deportation , the Secretary of ORG remains satisfied that his temporary release from detention would not be justified . He has concluded the applicant could not be safely released , subject to restrictions , in view of the nature of the threat posed by him . "
Judgment was given on DATE

( NORP v. Secretary of ORG for ORG , ex parte PERSON , unreported ) . Mr Justice PERSON in ORG rejected the application for habeas corpus , on the ground that " the detention per se was plainly lawful because the Secretary of ORG [ had ] the power to detain an individual who [ was ] the subject of a decision to make a deportation order " . In connection with the application for judicial review of the Secretary of ORG 's decision to detain PERSON , the Judge remarked : PERSON

" I have to look at the decision of the Secretary of ORG and judge whether , in all the circumstances , upon the information available , he has acted unlawfully , or with procedural impropriety , or perversely to the point of irrationality . I am wholly unable to say that there is a case for such a decision , particularly bearing in mind that I do not know the full material on which the decisions have been made ... [ I]t is obvious and right that in certain circumstances the Executive must be able to keep secret matters which they deem to be necessary to keep secret ... There are no grounds , in my judgment , for saying or even suspecting that there are not matters which are present in the Secretary of ORG 's mind of that kind upon which he was entitled to act ... "

CARDINAL . The current position with regard to the protection of human rights in GPE generally and in GPE more specifically was a matter of dispute between the parties . A substantial amount of evidence was presented to the ORG on this issue , some of which is summarised below . ORG

CARDINAL . The Government submitted that it appeared from NORP press reports collated by ORG that the number of lives lost in GPE from terrorism had decreased dramatically . In DATE the figure was CARDINAL , in DATE it was CARDINAL , and in DATE it was DATE . The former Chief Minister of GPE , PERSON , was assassinated in DATE ; that aside , there was little terrorist activity and CARDINAL terrorist - related deaths in the region in DATE .

CARDINAL . Furthermore , democracy had returned to the ORG : almost all factions of ORG , the main NORP political party , had united and were set to contest the next general election as one entity and the PERSON by - election passed off peacefully , with a turn - out of PERCENT .

CARDINAL . ORG continued to receive complaints about the GPE police . However , in DATE these had related mainly to extortion rather than to politically - motivated abuses and they were consistently told that there was now little or no politically - motivated police action in GPE .

CARDINAL . Steps had been taken by the NORP authorities to deal with the remaining corruption and misuse of power in GPE ; for example , there had been a number of court judgments against police officers , a " PERSON " ( ombudsman ) had been appointed and the new Chief Minister had promised to " ensure transparency and accountability " . ORG ( " NHRC " ) , which had reported on ORG ( see below ) continued to strengthen and develop . ORG
CARDINAL . The ORG visited GPE in DATE and reported as follows :

" The complaints of human rights violations made to ORG broadly into CARDINAL categories . Firstly , there were complaints against the police , of arbitrary arrests , disappearances , custodial deaths and fake encounters resulting in killings ... ORG

There was near unanimity in the views expressed by the public at large that terrorism has been contained ... [ A ] feeling was now growing that it was time for the police to cease operating under the cover of special laws . There were very strong demands for normalising the role and functioning of the police and for re - establishing the authority of the ORG over the police . The impression that ORG has gathered is that ... ORG level is not at present in a position to inquire into complaints of human rights violations by the police . In the public mind there is a prevailing feeling of the police being above the law , working on its own steam and answerable to none ... The Commission recommends that the Government examine this matter seriously and ensure that normalcy is restored ... "

CARDINAL . In addition , in its DATE report for DATE , the ORG recommended , as a matter of priority , a systematic reform , retraining and reorganisation of the police throughout GPE , having commented : PERSON " The issue of custodial death and rape , already high in the priorities of the Commission , was set in the wider context of the widespread mistreatment of prisoners resulting from practices that can only be described as cruel , inhuman or degrading . "

CARDINAL . The reports to ORG in DATE of the Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel , inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment and in DATE of the Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial , summary or arbitrary executions and ORG on enforced and involuntary disappearances recounted that human rights violations on the part of the security forces were widespread in GPE .
For example , in his DATE report , the Special Rapporteur on torture commented on the practice of torture in police custody : ORG

" It is apparent that few incidents , in what is credibly alleged to be a widespread , if not endemic , phenomenon are prosecuted and even fewer lead to conviction of the perpetrators . It is to be noted that very many cases that come to the attention of the Special Rapporteur are those that result in death , in other words , those where torture may have been applied with the most extreme results . This must be a minority of cases of torture in the country [ GPE ] . "

CARDINAL . The DATE ORG report on GPE told of human rights abuses perpetrated by the GPE police acting outside their home State : PERSON " GPE police hit teams again in DATE pursued NORP militants into other parts of GPE . On DATE , GPE police shot and killed PERSON , a man they identified as a NORP terrorist ... in LOC . The Government of LOC claimed that it had not been informed of the presence of GPE police in LOC , seized PERSON 's body and weapons and barred the departure of the police team until the ORG Chief Minister apologised . "

CARDINAL . In contrast , the most recent ORG report ( DATE ) declared that insurgent violence had largely disappeared in GPE and that there was visible progress in correcting patterns of abuse by the police . It continued : ORG

" Killings of NORP militants by police in armed encounters appear to be virtually at an end . During DATE ] , CARDINAL persons were killed in police encounters . Attention was focused on past abuses in GPE by press reports that CARDINAL of bodies , many allegedly those of persons who died in unacknowledged police custody , were cremated as ' unclaimed ' during DATE or discovered at the bottom of recently drained canals . "

CARDINAL . ORG took account of allegations of the extra - territorial activities of the GPE police in the case of PERSON v. Secretary of ORG for ORG ( DATE , unreported ) , which related to an appeal by a politically active NORP against the Secretary of ORG 's refusal to grant him political asylum . The appellant drew the attention of the tribunal to a story in ORG of DATE , which reported the killing by the GPE police of CARDINAL NORP fighters in LOC . The chairman of the tribunal remarked :

" We should say that we do not accept [ the representative of ORG ] view of this document , that it was more probably based on imaginative journalism than on fact . In our view , it affords valuable retrospective corroboration of the material set out above , demonstrating that the GPE police are very much a law unto themselves , and are ready to track down anyone they regard as subversive , as and when the mood takes them , anywhere in GPE . "

CARDINAL . In its report of DATE , " GPE police : beyond the bounds of the law " , ORG similarly alleged that the GPE police were known to have carried out abductions and executions of suspected NORP militants in other GPE outside their jurisdiction . ORG in GPE had reportedly taken serious note of the illegal conduct of the GPE police , publicly accusing them of " highhandedness and tyranny " and had on several occasions DATE ordered investigations into their activities . Following the killing of a NORP in GPE in DATE , which provoked an angry reaction from ORG , the ORG Secretary had convened a meeting of all director generals of police on DATE to discuss concerns expressed by certain GPE following the intrusion by the GPE police into their territories . CARDINAL of the stated aims of the meeting was to try to work out a formula whereby the GPE police would conduct their operations in cooperation with the respective ORG governments .

CARDINAL . In its DATE report , " GPE : Determining the fate of the ' disappeared ' in GPE " , ORG claimed that high - profile individuals continued to " disappear " in police custody . Among the examples cited were the general secretary of the human rights wing of the NORP political party , PERSON , who was reportedly arrested on DATE and had not been seen since .

CARDINAL . By CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ( b ) of LAW DATE ( " LAW " ) , a person who is not a NORP citizen is liable to deportation inter alia if the Secretary of ORG deems this to be " conducive to the public good " . ORG

CARDINAL . There is a right of appeal to an adjudicator , and ultimately to an appeal tribunal , against a decision to make a deportation order ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act ) except in cases where the ground of the decision to deport was that the deportation would be conducive to the public good as being in the interests of national security or of the relations between GPE and any other country or for other reasons of a political nature ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . This exception was maintained in ORG , which came into force in DATE .

CARDINAL . Cases in which a deportation order has been made on national security or political grounds are subject to a non - statutory advisory procedure , set out in paragraph CARDINAL of the Statement of Changes in Immigration Rules ( House of Commons Paper CARDINAL of DATE ) . ORG

The person concerned is given an opportunity to make written and/or oral representations to an advisory panel , to call witnesses on his behalf , and to be assisted by a friend , but he is not permitted to have legal representation before the panel . The Home Secretary decides how much information about the case against him may be communicated to the person concerned . The panel 's advice to the Home Secretary is not disclosed , and the latter is not obliged to follow it .

CARDINAL . GPE is a party to ORG on ORG ( " LAW " ) . A " refugee " is defined by LAW as a person who is outside the country of his nationality due to " a well - founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion " . ORG
Article CARDINAL of the DATE Convention provides : ORG

" CARDINAL . GPE shall not expel a refugee lawfully in their territory save on grounds of national security or public order . CARDINAL . The expulsion of such a refugee shall only be in pursuance of a decision reached in accordance with due process of law ... "
Article CARDINAL provides : ORG

" CARDINAL . No Contracting State shall expel or return a refugee in any manner whatsoever to the frontiers of territories where his life or freedom would be threatened on account of his race , religion , nationality , membership of a particular social group or political opinion .

CARDINAL . The benefit of the present provision may not , however , be claimed by a refugee whom there are reasonable grounds for regarding as a danger to the security of the country in which he is , or who , having been convicted by a final judgment of a particularly serious crime , constitutes a danger to the community of that country . "
CARDINAL . Rule CARDINAL of ORG ( House of Commons Paper CARDINAL of DATE ) provides that : ORG
" Where a person is a refugee full account is to be taken of the provisions of the LAW relating to the Status of Refugees ... "

CARDINAL . In a case where a person to be deported for national security reasons claims asylum , the Secretary of ORG must balance the interest of the individual as a refugee against the risk to national security ( NORP v. Secretary of ORG for ORG , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] ORG , p. CARDINAL - see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . A person may be detained under the authority of the Secretary of ORG after the service upon him of a notice of intention to deport and pending the making of a deportation order , and also after the making of an order , pending his removal or departure from the country ( paragraphs CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of Schedule III to LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Any person in detention is entitled to challenge the lawfulness of his detention by way of a writ of habeas corpus . This is issued by ORG to procure the production of a person in order that the circumstances of his detention may be inquired into . The detainee must be released if unlawfully detained LAW , section CARDINAL ) . CARDINAL application for habeas corpus on the same grounds may be made by an individual in detention , unless fresh evidence is adduced in support ( Administration of Justice Act DATE , section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) .
In addition , a detainee may apply for judicial review of the decision to detain him ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above and CARDINAL below ) .
In conjunction with either an application for habeas corpus or judicial review , it is possible to apply for bail ( that is , temporary release ) pending the decision of the court . ORG

CARDINAL . Decisions of the Home Secretary to refuse asylum , to make a deportation order or to detain pending deportation are liable to challenge by way of judicial review and may be quashed by reference to the ordinary principles of NORP public law . ORG

These principles do not permit the court to make findings of fact on matters within the province of the Secretary of ORG or to substitute its discretion for the Minister 's . The court may quash his decision only if he failed to interpret or apply LANGUAGE law correctly , if he failed to take account of issues which he was required by law to address , or if his decision was so irrational or perverse that no reasonable Secretary of ORG could have made it ( ORG v. ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL ORG Bench Reports , p. CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Where national security issues are involved , the courts retain a power of review , but it is a limited one because : ORG

" the decision on whether the requirements of national security outweigh the duty of fairness in a particular case is a matter for the Government to decide , not for the courts ; ORG alone has access to the necessary information and in any event the judicial process is unsuitable for reaching decisions on national security "
ORG v. Minister for ORG [ DATE ] Appeal Cases , p. CARDINAL , at p. CARDINAL ) .
See also NORP v. Secretary of ORG for ORG , ex parte PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL ORG , p. CARDINAL , where a similar approach was taken by ORG .
